title: 107_s1572
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members in accordance with Article 10 of the NATO Treaty. Congress called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, and emphasized the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in the enlargement process. Congress declared that Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria should be invited to join NATO as full members to enhance stability, freedom, and peace in Europe. At the Madrid Summit in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO in the first round of enlargement. The Alliance expects to invite more nations in the future that are willing and able to meet membership obligations. No European democratic country fulfilling NATO objectives will be excluded. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO pledged to continue welcoming new members who can uphold the principles of the North Atlantic Treaty and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. No European democratic country fulfilling the Treaty's objectives will be excluded from consideration for membership. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague, Czech Republic, to decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance in the next round of NATO enlargement. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several countries declared cooperation in seeking NATO membership. In June 2001, President George W. Bush expressed support for countries in Central and Eastern Europe seeking NATO membership, stating that it would be a success for all involved. Former President William J. Clinton expressed support for NATO membership for all European democracies willing to share responsibilities and not be used as pawns. He emphasized the importance of advancing freedom and avoiding past mistakes like Munich and Yalta. Former President William J. Clinton supports NATO membership for all European democracies willing to share responsibilities and prevent a gray zone of insecurity in Europe. SEC. 3. DECLARATIONS OF POLICY. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of the NATO Alliance as expressed in various acts and declarations since 1994. The Congress reaffirms support for NATO enlargement, endorsed by former President Clinton in 1996, urging NATO allies to work with the US towards this goal at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 designates Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria as eligible for assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The President can also designate other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe for assistance. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 designates Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria as eligible for assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe can also be designated for assistance under the program. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for fiscal year 2002 includes grants for Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, and Slovenia totaling $44,500,000. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for fiscal year 2002 includes grants for Bulgaria and Romania totaling $21,500,000. Amendment made to Security Assistance Act of 2000.
